channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl Developer who wants to learn Scala and NodeJS - West London
item.description: Love Perl but want to skill-up on another stack at your employerâ€™s expense?

item.title: Come work for Zoopla, one of London's success stories
item.description: Come and work at one of Londonâ€™s tech giants, with Perl Careers

item.title: Do you love customers? Senior Perl Developer with a product focus, London
item.description: Ever find yourself wishing you could see meaningful impact on users from your work? Trapped in a company with long release cycles and dubious release dates? Wish your ideas for product improvement didnâ€™t keep disappearing in to the Project Managerâ€™s backlog?

item.description: Saturday 3rd November 2018 London

item.description: September 7-8, 2018 Bern.

item.description: August 15-17, 2018, Glasgow. The Call for Papers is open.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: 2018.24 Discussion Redirect
item.description: The weekly awesome.

item.title: SQLite in Memory
item.description: A simple example in Perl using an in-memory version of SQLite for when you'd like to use SQL statements, but don't need to store the data on the disk.

item.title: Writing new testing tools with Test2
item.description: David Farrell explains how he wrote his first tool to extend the features of Test2.

item.title: A short introduction to App::rs
item.description: A very interesting demo of App::rs in the self explanatory Youtube video here.

item.title: More intelligent searched in Geo::Coder::Free
item.description: Added "intuitive" searches for Geo::Coder::Free. For example, when looking for a local favourite watering hole of mine, that I wouldn't be likely to search for "Rock Bottom Restaurant, Norfolk Ave, Bethesda, MD, USA". Instead, I'd be much more likely to search for "Rock Bottom, Bethesda, MD, USA".

item.title: Do you want to make your developers faster?
item.description: Introduce testing. Set up Continuous Integration. Refactor your code. Gabor, the editor of the Perl Weekly, can help you with any of these in Perl, Python, and other languages. Even remotely.

item.title: Assert::Refute - Unified and assertion tool
item.description: Konstantin explains why refute? As he claims successful prove run actually proves nothing. It's only the failures that are meaningful! This is similar to falsifiability concept in modern science: we don't prove a theory in experiment; instead, we try hard to refute it. Same goes for runtime assertions.

item.title: Baby Moose Recursion Dance
item.description: Following on from previous blog, where adding function call ability in an SQL select, here he is testing if 'Function' element will handle a function with more than one option.

item.title: Ambitious Baby Moose
item.description: Here John experiments if Driver::DBI can handle a function call in an SQL select.

item.title: Baby Moose in the Field
item.description: In this blog, John explains the ability to have static data as part of the elements array. This is accomplished by using the 'Param' class in place of the 'Element' class.

item.title: Meet the GitLab Web IDE
item.description: GitLab aiming for a real integrated development experience, accessible for everyone right within the GitLab UI, without anything to install. The idea grew from the "Repo editor" into that of the "Web IDE".

item.title: Parsing with Pictures
item.description: Pingali and Bilardi, explains how using their new framework, they go on to show that all LL-based and LR-based algorithms are simplifications of their Earley parser.

item.title: Dutch Perl Workshop 2018
item.description: Still time to submit talk. If you are planning to attend then please register your interest here.

item.title: A Call to Action: Polish Perl 6 First Steps Experience
item.description: There are several things you can help with, depending on your skillset. And before anyone protests, don't worry, there's one thing everyone is able to do.

item.title: #360 - Revitalizing blogs.perl.org
item.description:
Hi there,

About year ago, Andrew Walker, submitted a grant proposal to TPF to revitalize blogs.perl.org. Recently he blogged about its progress.

A very interesting beta release of the book The GraphQL Guide by John Resig.

Last but not the least I came across a CPAN distribution App::GitHubPullRequest which would be quite handy if you love doing PR.

Enjoy reading this week newsletter!
